entry.title: Weeknotes September 7th, 2024
entry.content:
What I Did

  • played my IBL games
  • has my usual Commander Night at my local gaming store
  • the transaction audit log work is proving to be a slog
  • discovered that you can configure PhpStorm's IdeaVim plugin via a .ideavimrc file to make the experience a little more Vim-like. Shoutout to Eric Johnson from php|architect for showing me how
  • flights booked for going to CascadiaPHP at the end of October
  • a testing scenario for the transaction audit log revealed that my chain-of-responsibility implementation for a series of validators for a rebate offer was just wrong, so off I went fixing it by switching to using pipelines in laravel. Don't worry, all the individual validators have tests

Longer Threads

I was going to do a longer piece on how I felt I was at a "crossroads" with my IDE choices. I know it sounds like dramatic whining.

I have been a Vim/NeoVim user for a long time. The HJKL muscle memory is burned in and I expect almost everything I use to be modal. For everything other than PHP, I use NeoVim.

But lately I am feeling...resentful about how all the tools I have started to rely on seem to have "becoming a subscription" as an aspirational goal. My renewal for my PhpStorm subscription is coming up and I am trying to decide if I can just not renew it and go back to NeoVim.

The ONLY reason I switched to using PhpStorm was because it made some other aspects of development work easier:

  • easily get Xdebug working and a slick interface for it
  • same with doing development work with Dockerized development environments
  • make it easy to run my tests inside that Dockerized environments
  • "intellesense" support baked in

There are other editors I have looked at -- Helix, Zed, and even the dreaded Emacs. Other than Emacs, the newer editors fall down when we get to the plugin and customization phage of creating a development environment.

From a pragmatic side, sticking with NeoVim due to intimate familiarity with it's modal nature and basic keybindings makes the most sense.

Emacs is an interesting choice because it is basically like NeoVim in that it has a long, rich history and is incredibly configurable. But learning a whole new series of keybindings? Seems very daunting.

Helix seems nice. Xdebug support appears to be very rough to get working. Have to have it for my PHP work, sorry. No idea if it can be made to support Xdebug running inside a Docker container. Again, need to check back later.

Zed -- no support for Xdebug. I'll check back later when they maybe bake in Debug Anywhere Protocol support.

So time to see if I can get NeoVim to give me the extra tooling that PhpStorm currently offers.

entry.content:

I read an excelled blog post from Steven Yegge where he talked about how he felt it was a bad time to be a junior developer, which dovetails nicely into me needing to deliver a talk at the end of October to the audience at Cascadia PHP about how a hater like me uses LLM's.

Can't ignore all the grifters and rent-seekers hanging around the industry and it does feel like a bubble is gonna pop.

entry.title: Weeknotes August 25, 2024
entry.content:
A little late this week.

What I Did

  • played my IBL games, where we continue to hover around the .500 mark
  • did a lot of work with Nova to build a dashboard for auditing transactions as they flow through our verification system
  • a fun Thursday of Magic: The Gathering playing commander
  • stomach still not great
  • played Doomlings and our 6+ year Apocalypse World game

Longer Threads

I tried out Emacs this week at work for a little bit each day and it is just different enough from what my Vim muscle memory wants that I have put it on hold.

Instead, I am concentrating on building new muscle memory to use home row mods to reduce how often I have to reach for the Shift and Alt keys. It's jarring to actually feel the pause as I stop to use the home row "shift".

entry.title: Weeknotes August 16, 2024
entry.content:
What I Did

  • played my IBL games via instructions (team managers create documents for how they want their team to be run)
  • finished writing all the tests for additional scenarios for the transaction processing job
  • no Magic: The Gathering this week as Commander night was my 26th wedding anniversary
  • stomach is feeling a little better -- I wonder if the ache I feel is because of damage all that stomach acid has done :(

Longer Threads

I came across a blog post from a developer about why they switched to Emacs and it make me wonder if I should try switching from Vim to Emacs. Again.

I tried it once before but couldn't duplicate my developer work flow. I feel like the combination of Emacs + xah-fly-keys is a great start since it would give me a similar modal editing experience that I expect in my editor.

Of course, the bigger issue is that I would have to set things up twice -- once on my work computer that ZiffDavis gave me and once on my own machine. I also pay for a license for PhpStorm and it is up for renewal soon.

Good to keep learning things. I've been using Vim so long that navigating via H-J-K-L is deeply embedded in muscle memory. I have noticed over the years that I don't really do much "web surfing" on my laptop -- I use my iPhone for that so having Vim bindings for my browser doesn't make mush sense.

Everything Else

  • going to be playing Doomlings this weekend as part of my monthly board gaming session
  • if you are interested in ergonomic keyboards I would check out the Glove80 from moergo

entry.title: Weeknotes August 9, 2024
entry.content:
Trying out something new to capture all the stuff giong on in my life with the idea of weeknotes. It's not that my ego think you want to know about all aspects of life but I am starting to feel like I lose track of some of the more ephemeral parts of my life in what I discover online.

Plus, I do think it is valuable for other developers with less experience getting paid to write code to see what it is actually like to be a senior developer. It's definitely not Magical Christmas Land but it's not "move this button to the left and implement this AI chatbot plugin" either.

What I Did

  • played my IBL games both on Sunday afternoon and Monday night
  • spent Monday afternoon checking out some different parks in London, ON with my wife (we like to do low-to-medium intensity hikes)
  • started working on adding a series of test scenarios to my work at ZiffDavis Shopping for a transaction processing job
  • doing reviews of PR's involving Python at work is an interesting challenge as I know just enough to have a basic understanding but not enough to catch edge cases as the moment
  • played Commander as usual on Thursday night
  • added deck lists to Archidekt for ones I am playing
  • continue to alter my eating habits while I deal with stomach issues (hopefully not becoming GERD

Longer Threads

I keep coming back to the phrase "post-testing software development world" and are finally organizing these thoughts. I should probably do a series of blog posts here about it. It's clear that things have definitely shifted in terms of commitment to testing and with an audience mostly-receptive to the concepts, a shift in how to teach and advocate for testing seems reasonable.

Everything Else

  • I continue to use the Reminders app on my phone to delay impulse purchase. Steamdeck? Sure, but I barely play the Switch I have
  • While my Nura ear buds are still in great shape I found a Canadian company called Sounds Good that designs and sells their own line of audio stuff
